prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for dumping my gf after her unannounced backpacking trip
Ok so this happened maybe three days ago, but first some context.

Me and my (now ex) girlfriend of 3 years lived in a 2 bedroom apartment which I pay for by myself, as I make enough money to afford it and I didn’t want to trouble her by pressing her with a bill for a place that is a tiny bit out of her price range, instead we use a meter and pay the bill through my account, with her compensating her  spend.
 
We also have always been big on trust since both of us have been cheated on in previous relationships, and didn’t want to go through that again in this one.

The fact that I pay solely this apartment is important as it allows her to spend her money on things like more expensive gifts and the occasional excursion for us (which of course I pay in part for). Also the fact that we are big on trust means we tell eachother A lot about our lives and future plans.

Anyways, she was always a fan of these trips abroad and loved travelling, and for the most part our trips were always fun. However, about three days ago she announced that she had bought tickets for a solo backpacking trip across South America which she was going to go on on Friday, and that she had been planning this for months.

First I asked if I could come, to which she said no because she would be “discovering herself” on this trip, and when I asked why hadn’t she told me she said because I wouldn’t have allowed (or at the very least not wanted) her to go, especially alone.  (Which is mostly true)

Well an argument ensued and at some point I finally put my foot down, it went something like this: 

Gf: “why can’t I just go explore the world and live life to its fullest”

Me: “you can, without me or the security of my home, pack your bags and get out”

I believe it was the right thing to do as she didn’t pay for the apartment anyways, and so didn’t have any right to demand to stay, plus I was willing to give her money for a hotel for a week, which she refused.

That night she went to her parents home an hour away and my phone was blown up with people calling me a controlling asshole and the like, my question is am I really an asshole for this?

TLDR: girlfriend popped a surprise solo trip on me 5 days before she left, saying she wanted to go alone and had been planning it for months, I kicked her out my house. 


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the Ask Me Anything (AITA) post is in the wrong for breaking up with his girlfriend after she went on an unannounced backpacking trip. 

First, some key points from the scenario: They've been together for 3 years, live in an apartment he pays for, with a shared bill. They value trust a lot because both have been cheated on before. The girlfriend planned a solo trip she hadn't told him about, saying she wanted to "discover herself," and when he didn't agree, he told her she could leave his place since she didn't pay for it.

Now, considering their living arrangement. He paid for the apartment, and she helped cover the expenses through a meter. If she's not paying for it, does he have the right to ask her to leave? Well, legally, if they're in a lease together, she might still have rights, but if he's the sole leaseholder, maybe he can ask her to leave. However, relationships aren't just legal; they're emotional. The question is whether his reaction was proportionate.

He gave her money for a hotel, which he says she refused. So maybe he tried to be accommodating. But kicking her out just because she went on a trip he didn't agree with? That seems harsh. They both value trust, so maybe transparency was a key part of their relationship. She had been planning it for months and didn't tell him, which could be a breach of trust. But on the other hand, she has the right to travel, even if he disapproves. 

The argument is that he didn't support her decision, which led to the breakup. But was dumping her immediately after the argument the right move? Maybe he felt it was a deal-breaker, but sudden separation can be seen as extreme. People have different boundaries. However, since he's the one paying for the apartment and they had issues with trust, maybe he felt justified in making a stand. 

Another angle: the girlfriend might have felt her autonomy was invaded by his reaction. She wanted to travel alone, which is a personal choice. His response could be seen as controlling, even if he tried to be fair by offering hotel money. 

But he's asking if he's in the wrong. Considering the AITA context, often the community looks at communication and mutual respect. Did he communicate his concerns before the breakup? He did have an argument, but the final line about her leaving might have been a reaction. Maybe he should have tried to work through it instead of ending things immediately. 

In conclusion, there are valid points on both sides. He might feel betrayed by the lack of communication, but her right to travel solo is hers. However, his reaction of asking her to leave the home could be seen as disproportionate, especially if they were in a committed relationship. So, the answer might lean towards A (he's in the wrong) because breaking up over a disagreement about travel, especially in a relationship built on trust, without considering other options, could be seen as harsh.
